item.title: Design by Refinement: Sorting by Refinement
item.description: In the last posts we’ve been studying refinement, and how to utilize refinement into a methodical approach to describe a system and a proposed solutions. Now let’s apply it to a simple example, sorting. This post has a paring with a video Designing Sorting This article is intended to be paired with it’s accompanying video. Before we begin, let’s think about what we want to accomplish: We want to express the essence of sorting.

item.title: Design by Refinement: TDD is not Design
item.description: American Sign Language has this beautiful word roughly translated to blur or smear. It means to blur details of a situation in order to see some greater value. It’s similar to the idea of not seeing the forest for the trees… in order to see the forest, the bigger picture, you need to blur the details. In principle Test Driven Development (TDD1) is an implementation technique. TDD promises to help it’s practitioners build the described design, and not overbuild.

item.title: 21st Century Proof :: Structure makes it possible, hard work makes it probable
item.description:
• A new way of expressing: “work smarter not harder” -> Structure makes it possible, hard work makes it probable.
  • Detail can obscure the big picture. Structure can help, if it allows for a personalized, or tunable about of illumination.
  • A proof is not easy if we must read the entire proof to understand.

item.description:
• Learning together is more fun, and you may not be as self-taught as you believe.

  • The more you learn, the more challenging the material becomes to continue growing. (a.k.a. Duh, but it took me time to realize it, regardless)

item.title: The World Is Not Incremental
item.description:
I’ve been struggling to understand the stress the TLA⁺ community is putting on the presence of math in the specifications. Namely, that specifications are not programming, and the math simplifies, by abstraction, the system.

What exactly is being simplified by using math, instead of “programming”?

During TLA⁺ study group this week, we discussed at least 1 aspect that applying math simplifies the description of our systems $$\rightarrow$$ The number of states.
